titleproper.value: Guide to the Brooklyn and Bronx lodges of the Vasa Order of America records <num>ARC.111</num>

author.value: Collection processed by Lenge L. Hong

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2019-06-06T21:04:00</date>

unittitle.value: Brooklyn and Bronx lodges of the Vasa Order of America records

extent.value: in five manuscript boxes, one record carton, one oversize box, and one artifact box.

abstract.value: The records of the Brooklyn and Bronx lodges of the Vasa Order of America consist of documents and ephemera from a number of Brooklyn- and Bronx-based member lodges of the Vasa Order of America, the largest Swedish-American fraternal organization in the United States. The organization was named after the Vasa family of the Swedish royal line that founded the modern state of Sweden in the 16th century and established Lutheranism as the state religion under Gustav Vasa (1496-1560), the first King of Sweden, elected in 1523.  The bulk of the collection is comprised of minutes of lodge meetings, lodge membership records, yearly and twice-yearly financial reports from the individual lodges, and ephemera, covering the period 1906 to 1982, with the bulk of the material spanning the 1920s to the 1970s.  The collection also contains a limited amount of lodge correspondence and records from subsidiary Vasa organizations, and constitutions and bylaws. Earlier materials are in Swedish and then gradually switch to English around the mid-20th century, and provide a glimpse into the process of lodge and member assimilation.  Finally, the collection also includes a small amount of material from other Swedish-American organizations, especially Agne Lodge #101 of the Independent Order of Vikings, which shared a meeting house with the Vasa Order of America at 465 Dean Street in Brooklyn.  These non-Vasa materials have been given their own series within the collection.

p.value: Identification of item, date (if known); Brooklyn and Bronx lodges of the Vasa Order of America records, ARC.111, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

While Syskonkedjan #306, Strängnäs #371, and Harmony #476 all discussed merging with Nordstjernan #89, only Strängnäs appears to have done so, also around 1970.  Syskonkedjan #306 appears to have merged with the newly-formed Nobel-Liljan #64 instead, and Harmony #476 seems to have done the same in March of 1973.  As of 2006, Nobel-Liljan was meeting at the Salem Auditorium at 450 67th Street in Brooklyn.

Of the 11 Brooklyn Vasa lodges featured in the collection's materials (Sture #33, Valkyrian #35, Nobel #64, Nobel-Liljan #64, Nordstjernan #89, Liljan #107, Olympic #235, Björn #275, Syskonkedjan #306, Strängnäs #371, and Harmony #476), roughly half are represented only by a name on a single document or list. Lodges Nobel #64, Nobel-Liljan #64, Nordstjernan #89, Liljan #107, Syskonkedjan #306, and Harmony #476, however, are extensively documented.  Of the four Bronx Vasa Order lodges mentioned (Thor/Thora #39, Gösta-Saga #78, St. Erik #338 and Washington #584), only St. Erik #338 is extensively documented.  Lodge Agne #101 of the Independent Order of Vikings is documented by the bulk of the material in the <emph render="bold">Independent Order of Vikings</emph> series.  Tingvalla #71 of the Independent Order of Vikings, and Rurik #69 of the Independent Order of Svithiod, are also briefly represented in this series.

dsc.value:
Series 1: Minutes of lodge meetings33130.92 Linear Feetin one manuscript box and one record carton.1920-1970Scope and Contents

This series contains minutes of the local lodge meetings for St. Erik #338, Liljan #107, and Harmony #476, ranging from 1920 to 1970. The minutes for St. Erik are especially rich; they are entirely in Swedish, continuously cover the years 1918 to 1941, and contain numerous clippings and flyers pasted into the minute books, documenting the lodge's many events and activities. The minutes of Harmony #476 cover the period 1935 to 1973, with small gaps throughout and a larger gap from 1939 to 1945. They are in generally good condition, though a few pages are torn entirely in half. The minutes of the last meeting contain the procedures of the merger with Nobel-Liljan. The minutes of Liljan #107 cover the merger-heavy period 1968 to 1970, and are mostly in Swedish. Some minutes also contain informal lists of benefits paid out to members.

Series 2: Constitutions and bylaws33140.04 Linear Feetin one record carton.1929-1970Scope and Contents

This series contains copies of the constitution of the Vasa Order of America, as well as the bylaws of four lodges: New York District #4, 1940 to 1963; Nobel-Liljan #64, circa 1970; Harmony #476, circa 1957; and St. Erik #338, 1929 to 1970. Also included are copies of the proceedings and recommendations from the Grand Lodge conventions, 1962 and 1966, and the New York District #4 conventions, 1960 to 1967.

Series 3: Correspondence33150.1 Linear Feetin one record carton.1920-1973Scope and Contents

This series contains approximately 50 items of lodge correspondence between the years 1920 and 1973. A number of the negotiations and logistics of the lodge mergers of the early 1970s are documented, as well as various activities. Nobel #64, Nordstjernan #89, Liljan #107, St. Erik #338, and Harmony #476 are represented.

Series 4: Financial records33160.36 Linear Feetin one record carton.1906-1975Scope and Contents

This series contains annual financial reports from the Grand Lodge, 1963; New York District #4, 1959 to 1969; the Vasa Club of Brooklyn, 1961 and 1965; Nobel #64, 1947 to 1970; Nobel-Liljan #64, 1970 to 1971; Nordstjernan# 89, 1906 to 1975, with intermittent gaps from 1909 to 1961; Liljan #107, 1966 to 1970 (missing 1969); St. Erik #338, 1916 to 1949 (missing 1917 and 1935); and Harmony #476, 1934 to 1971 (missing 1941 to 1944). These reports are rich sources of information, as they not only include a financial report for the lodge, but a list of lodge officers, new members, active and passive members, and members who transferred or deceased. Some of these reports also contain interleaved trustees reports and treasurers' reports. Many are in Swedish.

Series 5: Membership records33180.83 Linear Feetin two manuscript boxes.1907-1969Scope and Contents

This series contains several kinds of lodge membership records ranging from 1907 to 1969. First and most numerous are applications for membership in lodges Nobel #64, circa 1949 to 1967; Nordstjernan #89, 1909 to 1963; Liljan #107, 1907 to 1969; Syskonkedjan #306, 1915 to 1968; and Harmony #476, 1934 to 1965. Many applications are in Swedish. Not all applications are dated, so they have been arranged alphabetically by surname of applicant, with female members who applied while single filed under their maiden names. Since Nobel was founded in 1904, it is safe to assume that these forms do not represent a complete set for that lodge, and probably not for the other lodges either. This series also includes membership update forms returned by members of Nobel #64, Nobel- Liljan #64, Liljan #107, Syskonkedjan #306, and Thora #39. There is also a pad of carbon copy "membership change reports" from Nobel #64 only, and several membership lists.

Series 6: Subsidiary organizations and activities33200.21 Linear Feetin one manuscript box.circa 1933-1980Scope and Contents

This series contains materials from subsidiary organizations and activities of the Vasa Order of America, circa 1933 to 1980. These include financial records, correspondence and receipts from the United Vasa Building Association, 1947 to 1980; financial records and correspondence pertaining to the Swedish Home for Aged People in Staten Island, 1944 to 1964; bylaws, records, correspondence, and a blank membership card for the New York District Lodge #4 Blood Fund, 1956 to 1974; an undated address book of subscribers to the Vasa Star; a few documents related to the Vasa children's clubs (barnklubben), circa 1933 to 1966; a blank advertising order form for the Vasa Radio Hour, circa 1932; and miscellaneous correspondence related to annual Sweden Day celebrations, 1958 to 1969.

Series 7: Ephemera33210.88 Linear Feetin one manuscript box.1934-1973Scope and Contents

This series contains ephemera from 1934 to 1973. Materials include several souvenir programs, including a 1934 visit of Vasa members to Stockholm (in Swedish); the golden anniversary celebrations of Nobel #64, 1954 and New York District Lodge #4, 1952; and the 23rd and 25th Conventions of the Grand Lodge of the Vasa Order of America, 1954 and 1962. Other materials include a large, hardcover Vasa songbook in Swedish from 1947; a newspaper clipping; several pieces of promotional material from the Scandinavian restaurant and banquet hall "Iceland"; a card with song lyrics in Swedish; a funeral card and service for a deceased member; blank order forms for Vasa merchandise; and two photographs. Also, one certificate from this series is housed in the oversize box.

Series 8: The Independent Order of Vikings33230.88 Linear Feetin one manuscript box.1908-1951Scope and Contents

This series contains material from the Independent Order of Vikings and other Scandinavian-American organizations covering the period 1908 to 1951. The bulk of the series relates to lodge Agne #101 of the Independent Order of Vikings, which was based in Brooklyn and also met at the Vasa Club on Dean Street. Material pertaining to the Independent Order of Vikings and Agne #101 includes copies of constitutions, bylaws, and amendments from 1923 to 1940; several ritual books from 1909 to 1934; correspondence (mostly in Swedish); membership lists; receipts; and ephemera, 1934 to 1951. The remaining material contains certificates and ephemera from other Swedish-American and Scandinavian-American organizations that have been active in the New York City area. Four certificates from this series are located in the oversize box.

Series 9: Artifacts33251 Linear Feetin one artifact box.1928Scope and Contents

This series contains three wooden lottery boxes used by the lodges. Two boxes contain wooden and ceramic or glass marbles, and one of these boxes carries an inscription reading "Till Logen Strängnäs #371 på 10 årsdagen Mars 17 1928 / Från Logerna Valkyrian #35 Sture #33" ("To Lodge Strängnäs #371 [on] their 10th anniversary March 17, 1928 / From Lodges Valkyrian #35 [,] Sture #33"].
